required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Manipulation of the Ankle Joint on Gait
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Manipulation of the Tibiotalar Joint on Gait

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if manipulation of the ankle improves some measurable characteristics of how a person walks. The investigators hypothesize that the ankle will be able to bend better after manipulation and thus improve walking speed and reduce differences between the two limbs.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: Subjects will pick the speed they want to walk on the treadmill but will be blinded to their choice. The actual speed chosen will be recorded.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in side-to-side difference in stance phase
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of the change in the difference in single stance phase between the left foot and right foot.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in difference in step length from side-to-side
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of the change in the difference in step length between the left foot and right foot

arm_group.description: Treatment will consist of manipulation of the tibiotalar joint intended to produce anterior to posterior glide of the tibia on the talus
Sham manipulative procedure of the tibiotalar joint.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Students will be screened for eligibility by testing their ability to perform a squat.
Exclusion Criteria:
- a recent (within one month) ankle sprain
- evidence of ankle instability
- cardiac condition

facility.name: University of Bridgeport College of Chiropractic Human Performance Laboratory
